1.text: And now, laughed at me, Have the younger in days than I, Whose fathers I have loathed to set With the dogs of my flock.

2.text: Also—the power of their hands, why is it to me? On them hath old age perished.

3.text: With want and with famine gloomy, Those fleeing to a dry place, Formerly a desolation and waste,

4.text: Those cropping mallows near a shrub, And broom-roots is their food.

5.text: From the midst they are cast out, (They shout against them as a thief),

6.text: In a frightful place of valleys to dwell, Holes of earth and clefts.

7.text: Among shrubs they do groan, Under nettles they are gathered together.

8.text: Sons of folly—even sons without name, They have been smitten from the land.

9.text: And now, their song I have been, And I am to them for a byword.

10.text: They have abominated me, They have kept far from me, And from before me have not spared to spit.

11.text: Because His cord He loosed and afflicteth me, And the bridle from before me, They have cast away.

12.text: On the right hand doth a brood arise, My feet they have cast away, And they raise up against me, Their paths of calamity.

13.text: They have broken down my path, By my calamity they profit, ‘He hath no helper.’

14.text: As a wide breach they come, Under the desolation have rolled themselves.

15.text: He hath turned against me terrors, It pursueth as the wind mine abundance, And as a thick cloud, Hath my safety passed away.

16.text: And now, in me my soul poureth itself out, Seize me do days of affliction.

17.text: At night my bone hath been pierced in me, And mine eyelids do not lie down.

18.text: By the abundance of power, Is my clothing changed, As the mouth of my coat it doth gird me.

19.text: Casting me into mire, And I am become like dust and ashes.

20.text: I cry unto Thee, And Thou dost not answer me, I have stood, and Thou dost consider me.

21.text: Thou art turned to be fierce to me, With the strength of Thy hand, Thou oppressest me.

22.text: Thou dost lift me up, On the wind Thou dost cause me to ride, And Thou meltest—Thou levellest me.

23.text: For I have known To death Thou dost bring me back, And to the house appointed for all living.

24.text: Surely not against the heap Doth He send forth the hand, Though in its ruin they have safety.

25.text: Did not I weep for him whose day is hard? Grieved hath my soul for the needy.

26.text: When good I expected, then cometh evil, And I wait for light, and darkness cometh.

27.text: My bowels have boiled, and have not ceased, Gone before me have days of affliction.

28.text: Mourning I have gone without the sun, I have risen, in an assembly I cry.

29.text: A brother I have been to dragons, And a companion to daughters of the ostrich.

30.text: My skin hath been black upon me, And my bone hath burned from heat,

31.text: And my harp doth become mourning, And my organ the sound of weeping.
